help.title: System User Guide
help.subtitle: Understand what each module does and why the configuration order matters

flowDiagram.title: System Configuration Flow
flowDiagram.subtitle: Modules have data dependencies — you must follow this order for invoice generation to work correctly. Click any node to navigate to that module.

description.title: Why this configuration order?
description.step1: Configure GCP Connections first: the system needs credentials to call GCP APIs and auto-populate billing accounts and project names — preventing manual entry errors
description.step2: Create Customers next: every billing account, project, pricing rule, and invoice must belong to a customer — customers are the top-level container
description.step3: Set up Billing Accounts and link to customers: GCP costs are summarized by billing account ID — this linkage tells the system which customer owns each account's costs
description.step4: Create Projects under billing accounts: cost data is tagged by project ID — the chain Project → Billing Account → Customer enables full cost attribution
description.step5: Configure Product Groups and Pricing Lists: groups turn hundreds of SKU lines into readable categories; pricing lists define the reseller price charged to customers (not the GCP list price)
description.step6: Import cost data: with projects and product groups in place, every cost record can be matched to its customer and category
description.step7: Run Invoice Batches: the system automatically applies pricing rules and credits per customer, generating draft invoices for the entire billing month in one go
description.step8: Review, lock, and record payments: locking prevents accidental changes and satisfies audit requirements; recording payments closes the accounts receivable cycle

quickStart.title: Quick Start
quickStart.description: Follow this order — each step has dependencies on the previous ones:
quickStart.step1: (Super admin) Go to GCP Connections and add a service account — the system needs this to call GCP APIs and auto-fill project names and billing account lists
quickStart.step2: Go to Customers, create a customer, and bind the GCP connection you just configured — the customer is the top-level container, and binding ensures API calls use that customer's own credentials
quickStart.step3: Go to Billing Accounts, add GCP billing account IDs and link them to the customer — this is how costs get attributed to the right customer
quickStart.step4: Go to Projects, enter GCP project IDs — the system auto-fetches names and project numbers from GCP. Link projects to billing accounts and customers
quickStart.step5: Go to Product Groups to create categories (e.g. Compute, Storage), then go to Pricing Lists to configure discount rules — these determine invoice line items and final amounts
quickStart.step6: Go to Cost Imports to import raw GCP billing data — the system matches each cost record to a customer (via project) and a category (via SKU)
quickStart.step7: Go to Invoice Runs, select the billing month, and execute — the system generates draft invoices for all customers; review, lock, and send when ready

gcpConnections.title: GCP Connections (Super Admin Only)
gcpConnections.description: Stores GCP service account credentials or API keys. The system uses these to call GCP APIs. Binding a connection to a customer ensures API calls for that customer use their own credentials — enforcing data isolation at the API layer.
gcpConnections.step1: Add one connection per GCP account — paste the service account JSON and credentials are extracted automatically
gcpConnections.step2: In Customer Management, bind this connection to the corresponding customer — when that customer's users call GCP APIs (billing account lookup, project name sync), only their own GCP account data is returned
gcpConnections.step3: Click "Test" to verify the connection — the test calls the GCP Billing API and shows which billing accounts are accessible

customers.title: Customers
customers.description: Customers are the top-level entity. Invoices, billing accounts, projects, and pricing rules all belong to a customer. Without a customer, there is no container to attach data to.
customers.step1: Create the customer with billing settings (currency, payment terms) — these directly affect invoice calculations
customers.step2: Bind a GCP Connection: ensures this customer's GCP API calls (billing account queries, project name sync) use their own credentials rather than the system-wide default
customers.step3: Assign a pricing list and credits — the pricing list determines discounted prices, credits are automatically deducted during invoice generation

billingAccounts.title: Billing Accounts
billingAccounts.description: GCP charges are summarized at the billing account level. Recording which billing accounts belong to which customer is the foundation of correct cost attribution.
billingAccounts.step1: Add the billing account ID from GCP Console (format: XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX) — or use the "Import from GCP" tab to auto-list accessible accounts
billingAccounts.step2: Link the billing account to a customer — when cost data is imported, the system uses this link to attribute charges to the correct customer

projects.title: Projects
projects.description: GCP cost data is tagged by project ID. Projects must be linked to a billing account and a customer to form the complete cost attribution chain.
projects.step1: Enter the GCP project ID — the system automatically calls the Resource Manager API to fetch the project name and number, avoiding manual entry errors
projects.step2: Link the project to a billing account: clarifies which billing account bears this project's costs
projects.step3: Assign to a customer: completes the chain Project → Billing Account → Customer — invoice runs use this chain to aggregate each customer's monthly costs

productGroups.title: Product Groups
productGroups.description: GCP bills contain hundreds of SKUs. Displaying them all on an invoice is unreadable. Product groups map SKUs into human-readable categories like "Compute" or "Storage".
productGroups.step1: Create groups first (e.g. Compute, Storage, Network, Database), then add the corresponding SKUs to each group
productGroups.step2: Product groups must be configured before importing cost data — the import process needs to know which group each SKU belongs to for correct categorization
productGroups.step3: Use "Browse by Category" (Service → Resource Family → Resource Group → Usage Type) or keyword search to find and add SKUs

pricingLists.title: Pricing Lists
pricingLists.description: As a GCP reseller, you charge customers differently from GCP list prices. Pricing lists define discounts or fixed prices per product group, and must be assigned to customers to take effect.
pricingLists.step1: Create a pricing list with a descriptive name (e.g. "Standard 2025") — including the year makes it easy to create new versions annually
pricingLists.step2: Add rules per product group — three types: percentage discount (e.g. 10% off), fixed unit price, or tiered pricing based on spend thresholds
pricingLists.step3: Assign the pricing list to a customer — invoice runs look up the customer's active pricing list to calculate the final invoice amount

credits.title: Credits
credits.description: Customers may have pre-paid deposits, promotional credits, or contractual balances. Credits are automatically deducted from invoice totals during invoice runs — no manual calculation needed.
credits.step1: Add a credit with type (promotional / contract / flex), amount, validity period, and optionally the billing account it applies to
credits.step2: Credits are automatically matched and applied during invoice batch execution — when one credit is exhausted, the next valid one is applied

costImports.title: Cost Imports
costImports.description: Invoice generation requires raw cost data. Each record contains project ID, SKU, usage quantity, and cost — imported from GCP billing exports.
costImports.step1: Projects and product groups must be configured first — cost records are matched to customers via project ID, and to categories via SKU
costImports.step2: After import, the system aggregates monthly costs per customer and per product group, which becomes the calculation basis for the next invoice run

invoiceRuns.title: Invoice Runs
invoiceRuns.description: An invoice run processes all customers for a given billing month in one operation — applying pricing rules, deducting credits, and generating draft invoices automatically.
invoiceRuns.step1: Select the billing month — the system checks whether cost data exists for that month and whether customers have pricing lists configured
invoiceRuns.step2: After execution, review each customer's draft invoice to verify amounts, line items, and applied discounts
invoiceRuns.step3: Lock invoices when correct — locked invoices cannot be modified, satisfying audit requirements. If errors are found, re-run the batch to generate a corrected version

payments.title: Payments
payments.description: Records actual payments received from customers, updates invoice status, and closes the accounts receivable cycle.
payments.step1: Select the invoice being paid, enter the amount, date, and reference number (e.g. bank transfer ID)
payments.step2: After recording, the invoice status updates to "Paid" — making it easy to reconcile and include in financial reports

reconciliation.title: Reconciliation
reconciliation.description: Compares system-calculated invoice amounts against GCP's raw billing data to catch discrepancies before invoices are sent to customers.
reconciliation.step1: Reconciliation depends on accurate cost import data — ensure the complete GCP billing export for the month has been imported
reconciliation.step2: Discrepancies usually indicate incorrect pricing rules or incomplete cost data — reconciliation results guide you to the root cause

users.title: User Management
users.description: Controls who can log in and what data they can see. Data isolation is enforced through "Customer Scopes" — this is the core multi-tenancy mechanism.
users.step1: Create users and assign roles (super_admin / admin / finance / viewer) — the role determines which operations they can perform
users.step2: Assign a "Customer Scope" to non-admin users — a user scoped to Customer A can only see Customer A's invoices, projects, and billing data; the backend filter is applied automatically
users.step3: Deactivate or adjust scopes promptly when someone leaves or changes roles — preventing data leakage

auditLogs.title: Audit Logs
auditLogs.description: Every data change is recorded: who did what, and when. Used for compliance audits, incident investigation, and evidence in billing disputes with customers.
auditLogs.step1: Filter by date range, user, or action type — e.g. "who locked this invoice and when"
auditLogs.step2: Regularly review high-privilege operations (delete, lock, scope changes) to ensure no unauthorized changes have been made

roles.title: Role Permissions
roles.superAdmin: Full system access — can manage GCP connections, users, and all customer data with no scope restrictions. Limit to 1-2 accounts per system.
roles.admin: Administrative access within assigned customer scopes — can manage customers, billing accounts, projects, and invoices, but only for their assigned customers.
roles.finance: Finance team access — can view invoices, record payments, and manage credits, but cannot modify customer configuration or system settings.
roles.viewer: Read-only access to data within assigned scopes. Suitable for customer portal accounts where the customer just needs to view their own invoices.

tips.title: Best Practices
tips.tip1: Never enter project names manually — the system auto-fetches them from GCP to ensure they match the official name exactly
tips.tip2: If you find an error after locking an invoice, re-run the invoice batch to generate a corrected version rather than unlocking the original
tips.tip3: Create one GCP Connection per customer account and bind it in Customer Management — this is the correct way to ensure multi-customer API data isolation
tips.tip4: Assign Customer Scopes (not admin roles) to customer-facing users — this ensures they only see their own data, enforced automatically by the backend
tips.tip5: Configure product groups before importing cost data — without them, imported costs will be uncategorized and cannot be properly grouped on invoices
